utterance: Pratik Dholabhai: I would say for me it's how do we make materials that can take CO2 out of the ocean.

annotations.ask question: The speaker is asking a question about making materials to take CO2 out of the ocean.

utterance: Jeffrey Long: That's interesting. I mean the concentration is so much higher in flue gas. Why not just go after that? I mean the advantage of the air of course is you can do it anywhere you don't have to be at a point source. But the ocean you have to be at the ocean. So why the ocean versus flue gas? I mean the ocean is a huge carbon sink so it's important to get it out of the ocean but it's still a pretty low concentration compared to a point source. And so you know the thermodynamics are just going to kill you I think in terms of the energy cost of getting it out. I mean it's already bad enough from air. From the ocean it's even more dilute. So I don't know. I mean maybe there's some trick with the pH of the ocean or something you can do but I'm not sure I see the advantage there. I mean it's a big problem but I don't see the advantage of going after the ocean. Maybe you can enlighten me.

annotations.ask question: The speaker asks for clarification and information on the approach of capturing CO2 from the ocean versus flue gas.
annotations.critical response: The speaker critically evaluates the approaches for CO2 capture, questioning the advantage of capturing CO2 from the ocean compared to flue gas.

utterance: Leo Liu: Yeah I think that's a great point. I think the advantage of the ocean is that it's a huge reservoir and so if you can get it out of the ocean you can make a big dent in the problem. And I think there are some tricks you can play with the pH. There's a recent paper in Nature that showed that you can use a bipolar membrane to split water and then use the protons to acidify the ocean and drive off the CO2. And then you can use the hydroxide to raise the pH back up and you can do this in a closed loop. So I think there are some clever things you can do. I'll put the article in the chat.

annotations.supportive response: The speaker is expressing agreement and providing a positive evaluation of the previous idea about capturing CO2 from the ocean.
annotations.develop idea: The speaker is expanding on an existing idea by suggesting a method for capturing CO2 from the ocean using a bipolar membrane.

utterance: Matt Green: Yeah I saw that paper it's pretty cool. I think the challenge there is the cost of the bipolar membrane. They're not cheap and you have to have a lot of them to make a difference. And then you have to worry about fouling and all that stuff. So I think it's a cool idea but I'm not sure it's practical. I think a better way to go is to use a liquid sorbent. You can use an amine or something like that and you can just bubble the air through it and then you can heat it up to release the CO2 and you can do that in a closed loop. And I think that's a more practical way to go. I think the challenge there is the energy cost of heating it up but I think there are ways to get around that. You can use waste heat from a power plant or something like that. So I think that's a more practical way to go.
